units.title: Neural induction with dual-SMAD inhibition
units.text: We use the dual-SMAD inhibitors dorsomorphin (4 μM) and SB-431542 (10 μM) in neurobasal media with the vitamin A-containing B27 supplement for neural induction (Figs. 1 and 2a–c).
units.rationale: This step describes the specific reagents and concentrations used to initiate neural differentiation from pluripotent stem cells.

units.title: Neural rosette formation and amplification with FGF2 and EGF
units.text: We treat the cultures of neuroepithelial cells with fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF2, 10 ng/mL) and epidermal growth factor (EGF, 10 ng/mL)59,60. In our preliminary experiments, we noticed that cultures without FGF2 exhibit impaired NR formation, limited organoid growth and increased cell death.
units.rationale: This details the critical growth factors and their concentrations required for neural rosette emergence and maintenance.

units.title: Manual isolation of single neural rosettes (SNRs)
units.text: We manually isolate SNRs that are ~200–300 μm in diameter for organoid generation (Fig. 2f). Cells in SNRs are characterized by the expression of the proliferation markers pH3 and KI67, neural progenitor markers SOX2 and NESTIN, and telencephalic markers PAX6 and FOXG143, suggesting telencephalic identity.
units.rationale: This specifies the size criteria and morphological features used to select viable SNRs for organoid derivation.

units.title: SNR propagation in suspension culture
units.text: We transfer isolated SNRs to a low-adhesion 96-well plate (one SNR per well) and maintain them on an orbital shaker in the N2/B27(with vitamin A) media with FGF2 and EGF for 2 weeks (Figs. 1 and 3).
units.rationale: This outlines the culture conditions and duration for SNR expansion into early organoids.

units.title: Embedding SNR-derived organoids in Matrigel
units.text: To promote further tissue growth, we adopted the approach developed by Lancaster and Knoblich27 and embedded SNR-derived organoids into Matrigel (MG) droplets (Fig. 5a). Following MG embedding, we observed notable transformations, including substantial tissue growth, migration of cells into MG and extensive radiation of fibers (Fig. 5b,c).
units.rationale: This describes the key step of MG embedding to enable organoid maturation and structural expansion.

units.title: Organoid maturation with neurotrophic factors
units.text: Between 3 and 4 months post-embedding, we treated organoids with brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), neurotrophin-3 (NT3) and glial-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) (Fig. 1) to promote neuronal survival, maturation and synapse development62,63.
units.rationale: This specifies the timing and composition of trophic factors added to drive functional neuronal maturation.

units.title: SNR isolation using a glass hook
units.text: Use the glass hook to isolate SNRs. • For clusters containing multiple NRs, cut them into ~200 × 200 µm pieces before proceeding to Step 37 to replate onto an MG-coated 35 mm dish • If working with isolated SNRs, proceed to Step 39
units.rationale: This provides the precise manual technique and tool used to isolate single neural rosettes from clusters.

units.title: Medium changes during SNR propagation
units.text: Change the medium every other day for 2 weeks by removing 50% of the old medium (150 μL) and adding 150 μL fresh amplification medium with 2× concentrations of FGF2 and EGF to achieve final FGF2 and EGF concentrations of 10 ng/mL.
units.rationale: This details the frequency and method of medium exchange to maintain optimal growth factor levels during organoid development.

units.title: Embedding organoids in Parafilm dimples with MG
units.text: Fill another 10 cm Petri dish with 15 mL organoid propagation medium (without FGF2 and EGF) and place it in the incubator. This dish will be used for MG droplet solidification in the incubator (Step 54). Transfer individual organoids to individual Parafilm dimples using a P200 pipette tip (first cut the tip to enlarge the tip opening to fit the organoid) (Fig. 5a). Remove excess media from the dimples using a P200 pipette. Perform this step under the stereoscope to avoid aspiration of the organoids. Retrieve P200 pipette tips from the −20 °C freezer and use the cold tips to draw up 30 μL thawed MG. Then, carefully add MG on top of the organoid in the Parafilm dimple. Use the same tip to reposition the organoid into the center of the MG droplet and remove bubbles if accidentally introduced.
units.rationale: This provides a step-by-step procedure for embedding organoids in Matrigel using Parafilm dimples and cold pipette tips.

units.title: Slice preparation for patch-clamp electrophysiology
units.text: Cut 350-µm-thick slices using the vibratome set to 100 Hz frequency, 1.2 mm amplitude and a slow (3–6 mm/min) forward movement velocity (Fig. 9b). Stop the vibratome after each slice. Under a magnifying glass, use a bent insulin needle to separate the slice from the remaining tissue, and transfer the slice into a maintenance beaker with bubbling ACSF using a wide Pasteur pipette.
units.rationale: This describes the precise vibratome settings and handling technique for preparing viable organoid slices for electrophysiology.
